For the sauce, our arrabbiata would be perfect. It's one of our most popular, it actually gets better after sitting for a day, and it's pretty foolproof to reheat. Plus it's got that little kick that makes people remember it. Maria makes huge batches of it anyway for the restaurant, so scaling up wouldn't be hard.

The mason jar idea is brilliant - I was imagining having to find some fancy packaging company, but you're right, I can literally start this week. And $8 feels reasonable... people spend that on fancy pasta sauce at the grocery store that's nowhere near as good as ours.

I'm getting excited about this, but I want to make sure I'm thinking it through. Should I mention it to my regular customers first, or just put up the sign and see what happens? And what if people love it - how do I know when I'm ready to scale up? I don't want to promise something I can't deliver consistently.

Also, I'm curious about your thinking on the pasta kits being 70-80% of dine-in price. That seems high to me - shouldn't it be cheaper since they're doing the work at home? Or am I thinking about this wrong?

<END>
